The refraction of light in a medium depends on the refractive index, which varies with the frequency (or wavelength) of light.
The frequency (f) and wavelength (λ) of light are related by: c = fλ, where c is the speed of light in the medium.

Diffraction is the bending of waves around obstacles and the spreading out of waves past small openings.
The degree of diffraction depends on the wavelength (λ) of the wave and the size of the obstacle or opening (d).
Diffraction is more pronounced when λ is comparable to or larger than d.
The larger the wavelength relative to the obstacle size, the more significant the diffraction.
